newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Jakarta call money traded at 8.0/8.5 percent.
newsitem.headline: Jakarta call money traded at 8.0/8.5 percent.

text.p: Jakarta call money was traded at 8.0/8.5 percent on Monday on ample liquidity, dealers said.

They said an early central bank injection of some 1.81 trillion rupiah seemed to flood the market. One dealer said the absence of value today trading due to a public holiday in the U.S. removed arbitrage opportunity with the swap market.
But one Japanese bank dealer said he would be cautious of upcoming tax payments as the amount might be higher due to the approaching end of the 1996/97 fiscal year on March 31.
He said businesses seemed to gradually return to normal after an extended Eid al-Fitr holiday last week.
Longer-term rates were edging down slightly from Friday due to ample rupiah supply. One- and three-month money were quoted at 13.00/13.25 and 13.75/14.00 percent, respectively.
The central bank kept its rates for bilateral SBIs stable. It offered seven-day at nine percent, 14-day at 10.0 percent, one- and three-month at 11.25 and 12.0 percent.
The average overnight interbank rate on Friday was 10.1 percent, compared with 9.85 percent on Thursday.
Bond dealers said prices remained stable in slow trading.
The yield of the benchmark PLN V/A bond was steady at 15.37 percent at the price of 105.25 percent.
